Designed and Developed by: Outside
Through this digital report, we hope to give you a glimpse into our company’s efforts towards becoming a responsible company.

We are excited to share with you our first digital report on our social and environmental performance.

Between the high start of Visit Nepal 2020 and then waiting for sound news in the media about travel restrictions after two lockdowns during the Covid-19 Pandemic, we were preparing for every possible scenario.

In these difficult times, our values were the guiding light: Community Empowerment, Environment Stewardship and Giving Back.
We went through the steps of reflection, realization and reconciliation in 2020 and slowly built back our business by 2021. Looking back in these past two tumultuous years, there’s only one word that sums it all: resilience.
Follow our journey as we look back to our efforts since 2019 and how we overcame the challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic to make the most of our resources.
2020 Impact Report

Designed and Developed by: Outside
Early 2020 was a hopeful time as the government had announced Visit Nepal Year 2020. We celebrated our gains from 2019 when the impact and sustainability department was set up at Royal Mountain Travel.
There was a 9% growth rate of our staff. We had set hefty goals to create more positive impact and expand our sustainability initiatives.

But the Covid-19 pandemic gave us a jolt. People all over the world lost or got separated from their loved ones. Many lost their income and jobs due to the government imposed lockdowns and economic uncertainties.

Amidst such uncertainties in Nepal, our team turned inwards to seek help.
While the offices closed due to the stringent lockdown restrictions from the government, we at Royal Mountain Travel worked on building solidarity among our team even when we felt disconnected from the physical office and the destinations.

We supported our sister company Community Homestay Newtwork's Project Koseli, to provide alternative sources of income for community based suppliers

We initiated Virtual Tours along with some local partners to engage our leaders and guides.
>
In these difficult times, our values were the guiding light: Community Empowerment, Environment Stewardship and Giving Back.

Our Commitments
to the Planet

1 2

While our physical and office-based work moved online, we had minimal office waste. We continued our collaboration with maintenance and recycling partners Khalisisi and Sajilo Marmat Sewa. We prioritised the use of our electric vehicles.

It was amazing to see our tour leaders induce much needed sustainable travel perspectives and help locals start the Panauti Bike Station and bike trails.

We focused on communication through Zoom where we conducted daily team building and motivational activities. We brainstormed how to make our trips sustainable and made preparations for rebuilding our website. We followed the innovation of virtual tours so that we could continue supporting the leaders and guides.

Commitment
to our People

1 2 3 4

We ensured that our staff were supported despite the stagnancy in the tourism sector. Our staff remained gender equal. Women empowerment continues to be our goal.

For more details

Tourist Guide Day was celebrated on 21st February 2020 at Hotel Traditional Comfort with our tour leaders taking social distancing in mind. We asked our Agents to send a video message of hope for our guides and leaders. We celebrated our guides being the unofficial brand ambassadors of the country

For more details
Women’s Day 2020 was celebrated in our office.

The virtual tours in collaboration with our local and international partners helped bring some much needed income support for guides and leaders. Similarly, one of our guides took leadership in his hometown for cleaning and repainting the mani walls, an important cultural heritage in the Khumbu region.

For more details

to our Community

Our communities remained resilient.

Leaders conducted Covid-19 training in the communities of Barauli, Nagarkot Nuwakot, Panauti, Patalekhet, Maipokhari and Bardiya.

Project Koseli was initiated in Barauli with investment in packaging equipment.

Designed and Developed by: Outside
A 10-part Sustainability Series was produced for learning about sustainability in Nepal.
For more details
Workshops were held for staff engagement.

Project Koseli

which we supported initially, expanded from 4 to 8 communities between 2020 and 2021 with the help of Booking Booster Grant.
Similarly, the number of Koseli products expanded from 10 to 19. Project Koseli has just begun to make sales and there is more to do. At Royal Mountain Travel, we are committed to supporting them.
Yoga sessions, sustainability training and product development consulting opportunities were given to Guides and Leaders.

New website was launched. We introduced ‘Impact Footprint’ to trip plans and descriptions as part of our commitment to sustainability.

Our commitment within our operations remained intact. Post lockdown, store management was carried out. Staff also were engaged in Travelife training. We continued our partnership with recycling and maintenance partners. While we could not expand our electric fleet like we aimed for, we prioritised their use.

With our partner Khalisisi, we have recycled 445 kgs of paper, 60 kgs of metal, 300 pieces of bottles and 20 kgs of plastic since 2019. We continue to be responsible and reduce consumption.

We focused on communication through Zoom where we conducted daily team building and motivational activities. We brainstormed how to make our trips sustainable and made preparations for rebuilding our website. We followed the innovation of virtual tours so that we could continue supporting the leaders and guides.

We promoted these
community based products this year

1 2
Community Homestay Eastern and Western Circuits

Travelers to Nepal can enjoy authentic accommodation throughout the country, from the jungles of the Terai to the Himalayas, and everything in between in both the east and the western regions of Nepal. For more details refer to:

For more details
Cooking with a family in Kathmandu

This cooking class includes interaction with a local Nepali family, who will take guests to shop for ingredients and spices and teach them how to cook a Nepali meal.

Our most popular community-based product this year

Bhaktapur Panauti Day Trip

This 6-hour tour begins from Kathmandu and takes its first sightseeing intermission at a legendary town, Bhaktapur. The highlights of this protected medieval city are traditional pottery, wood carving, beautiful temples, ponds and old traditional wooden houses. The tour continues to Panauti, a small village surrounded by green hills and holy rivers, that embodies the spirit of an ancient Newari community. While UNESCO world heritage site Bhaktapur showcases the best of Newari architectural skills, Panauti offers travellers an authentic experience of Newari hospitality and an opportunity to enjoy a local home-cooked meal.

We are constantly promoting alternative destinations in Nepal to ensure the benefits of tourism reach communities that have traditionally been left out.
97% of reviewers have given us very good ratings on Trip Advisor
It is always great when we are recognized for our good work
Read some of our reviews
We have a vibrant company culture which is a result of the gender and age diversity in our company and our frequent company gatherings.

We are a company that works together, eats lunch together and succeeds together.

50 staff in total with a 9% growth in employees this year
43% female staff in our workforce. 30% growth this year in female employees

Meet Shanti Ghising and Sita Banjara, our lady drivers that make the women behind e-wheels initiative successful.

Traditionally women have not been well represented in the travel industry, not only in Nepal but also worldwide, owing to various reasons. Meet our female tour leaders shattering gender stereotypes
1 2 3 4 5

Kalpana Bhattarai

Favorite Destination in Nepal

Annapurna Base Camp for its combination of nature and adventure

Favorite memory from a trip

Getting chased by buffaloes in the middle of nowhere from one of my Annapurna base camp trips last September.

Junu Shrestha

Favorite Destination in Nepal

Among the places I have visited, Upper Mustang is my favorite. It is an isolated place with a unique culture. Reaching the destination in itself is amazing, like entering a different country. Dhakmar, Lomanthang and Jhong caves are my favorite places in Upper Mustang. While the lovely, warm hearted people welcoming you with a smile make you feel at home, the buddhist flags, the spinning wheels and the monasteries make you feel at peace.

Favorite memory from a trip

Every trip is memorable for me. I enjoy meeting new people with different cultures, traditions, stories and experiences from around the world. It feels like the world comes to meet me in Nepal.

Shruti Shrestha

Favorite Destination in Nepal

Mardi Himal base camp for the stunning view of the mountains

Favorite memory from a trip

Every trip is memorable but I enjoy it the most when my clients are happy and are able to gather good memories from Nepal.

As a female tour leader, I want to encourage other women to be part of the travel industry. Many thanks to Royal Mountain Travel for supporting the advancement of women and creating a good working environment for us.

Jamuna Khatri

Favorite Destination in Nepal

Nagarkot because it is the best place to see the eight popular ranges in the Himalayas. I feel very refreshed after visiting Nagarkot, which also reminds me of my childhood.

Favorite memory from a trip

When an older person in a group I was leading referred to me as “Aama” (which means mother in Nepali) for taking care of him and the whole group like a mother. As he kept calling me “Aama”, the entire group also started calling me that. I felt a special emotional connection with all of the travelers as they were sad to leave Nepal and me.

Monica K.C.

Favorite Destination in Nepal

Pokhara because this place can offer a complete package consisting of adventure, nature, culture, religion and entertainment, among others. I also like Barauli Community Homestay.

Favorite memory from a trip

I have had lots of good memories while leading a trip but the one that I recall instantly is during one of my Annapurna trips when I was leading a group of 8 people. Throughout the trip, there were several incidents that took place as we walked from Ghandruk to Landruk that weren’t necessarily good but the way they happened gave us something to laugh and talk about. It was a rainy day, making the trails slippery and infested with leeches. All of us were struggling to get downhill and had nasty leech bites. Somehow we kept moving with the help of our porters and our assistant guide. Although everyone was strictly instructed to not take pictures while walking and to watch our steps, a young woman was taking a video. She missed a step and tumbled down a cliff. Luckily, we had almost reached the base so the steepness was not dangerous. As our assistant guide went to help her, she jumped on him and both of them started rolling down the cliff further. Others started laughing but were also scared at the same time. Fortunately, there were no serious injuries and all of us made it to our destination.

As we settled down and talked about the day, our stomachs started cramping because of laughing too much. What had happened could have been serious but at the end of the day it brought about lots of laughter considering how the events unfolded, making the trip memorable.

Meet Mohini, Ganga and Shristi who are currently undergoing training to become tour leaders
1 2 3

Mohini Khatri

Favorite Destination in Nepal

There are many destinations to choose from, but it has to be Pashupatinath Temple as it holds religious, cultural, traditional and historical significance. No matter how many times I visit the temple, the impact of visiting this site is always different and emotional.

Favorite memory from a trip

I was with a guest who was in her 80s. We were at Pashupatinath temple where we were observing post death rituals and how Hindus bid farewell to a departed soul for the last time. My guest got emotional and expressed that these rituals reminded her of losing her husband whom she missed dearly. She told me that life is beautiful and that we must cherish what we have. Traveling made her feel alive and being at the temple that day helped her let go of her emotions. I remember that day because it made me feel a special human connection that transcends cultures and nationalities.

Ganga Adhikari

Favorite Destination in Nepal

Annapurna Base Camp and Mardi Himal Base camp

Favorite memory from a trip

My favorite memory is from Mardi when I saw the mountains from so close that it felt like a wall of mountain right in front of my eyes. Also, the people I went with were great which made the whole trip better.

Shristi Shrestha

Favorite Destination in Nepal

Annapurna Base Camp for the varied landscape underneath the snowy peaks.

Favorite memory from a trip

One of my favorite memories is accompanying and motivating two older ladies in our group throughout one trek. This experience turned out to be a good lesson that I carry with me. I also enjoyed playing different roles like a friend, motivator, singer, dancer, guardian and a leader.

Besides this, I also appreciated learning from a female tour leader, Ms. Kalpana Bhattarai whom I admire very much for her strength, dedication, confidence and grace.

95% of our 179 suppliers in Nepal are local.
We are committed to using tourism as a force to uplift our local communities. For this, we take steps to ensure that we use local suppliers to the extent possible.
997 local people have received employment opportunities from us.
This includes 35 trekking guides, 32 tour leaders, over 90 porters, 68 staff and over 772 beneficiaries from our sister concern Community Homestay Network that started as a CSR initiative.

Kiran Namaste

Since its establishment in 2008, we have been supporting a local NGO that provides vocational training to single-mothers.
See Link

All of the T-shirts and clothing in our brand are stitched by the women of Kiran Namaste.

All the bed sheets and linens in our partner hotels Traditional Comfort and Traditional Stay is also made by the women of Kiran Namaste.

Impact in Focus

Helambu Climate Trek

No one is oblivious to the fact that the 2015 earthquakes caused severe damages and casualties in Nepal. For a country that is aspiring to increase the share of revenue from tourism, the earthquake was devastating. A lot of family-owned lodges and tea houses along trekking routes in Nepal were deprived of income and a source of livelihood. The Climate Trek project was aimed at supporting lodge owners in the Helambu region to rebuild their lodges with earthquake resistant materials while disseminating knowledge about sustainable energy supply, sustainable water supply, waste and sewage management.

We were one of the four local tour operators to support the Climate Trek project. Along with the other three tour operators, we did a scoping of the lodges in Helambu region and shortlisted local lodges to support based on the location, availability of land and interest of lodge owners. The lodges became operational in 2018. The impact created from the climate trek project includes an improvement in the quality of accommodation and the sustainability performance of the lodges. We have been promoting and marketing Helambu Climate Trek since this year.

Read more about Climate Trek project
100,000 plastic bottles saved from landfills*

*Assuming one person uses 200 plastic water bottles in a year. The 200 figure is taken as an average number of plastic water bottles our staff were using prior to the distribution of reusable water bottles.

2087 litres of fuel consumption avoided by using electric vehicles.

*Based on total distance travelled by Electric Vehicles and assuming a liter of fuel would be required for every 10 kilometers.

10+ Suppliers’ sustainability performance analyzed.

Four frequently used hotels in our network started eliminating plastic water bottles and providing clean purified water in reusable water bottles upon our recommendation. All of the community homestays in our network provide clean drinking water to our guests in reusable water bottles.

We are committed to saving water and electricity in our offices and this year we have partnered with a local company to conduct water and electricity audits.
This year we have also partnered with a local waste recycling agency to recycle waste. So far, this year we have recycled 198 kg of waste (Paper and Metals). In the coming year, we plan to push our recycling efforts further.
100% of our suppliers in areas where there is wildlife engage in ethical practices related to wildlife.
Our commitment towards Sustainable and Responsible Tourism is also reflected through our partners.
We are proud to be associated with companies such as Riksja Travel, Avontuur, Inspired Adventures, Shanti Travel, Erlebe Fernreisen, G Touring and G Adventures that give due importance to sustainability.

We are proud to receive the G Adventures Ripple Effect award for our contribution towards enabling the benefits of tourism to reach local communities

Our commitment
for 2020

1 2 3 4 5 6 7

Add more electric vehicles in our fleet

Since smaller cars can carry less people compared to bigger vehicles, the per capita carbon footprint for a small vehicle is higher. That is why we want to start replacing the smaller vehicles in our fleet with electric vehicles

Become carbon neutral in our operations

This year we have measured the carbon emissions from our operations. In the coming year, we will reduce our emissions and offset the remaining emissions to become carbon neutral.

Discuss retirement plans with older guides

As some of the guides in our network get older, we plan to discuss their retirement plans and identify areas where we can support them.

Promote more community-based products

As community-based tourism gets more traction around the world, we plan to develop and offer more exciting products in this area.

Train and appoint more female tour leaders

Next year we want to work towards increasing representation of women not only in our offices but also out in the fields.

Analyze the sustainability performance of all of our key suppliers and provide recommendations

We understand that while it is important for us to become a sustainable tour operator, we also need to influence other companies in our network to become more sustainable.

Conduct interactive sessions with guides on the topic of how to become more sustainable on the field.

We are as committed to becoming more sustainable on the field as we are to becoming more sustainable in our office operations. We plan to conduct regular interactive sessions with our tour leaders to become more sustainable overall.

Thank You

As we head into 2020, we are excited to carry forward this pursuit to become more sustainable and to push ourselves further as a responsible company.

We would like to thank all our partners and travelers for yet another rewarding year and for entrusting us with curating experiences. Hopefully we have helped you take a part of Nepal back with you.

For more information on Royal Mountain Travel, feel free to visit our website at https://royalmt.com.np/

For any questions and/or feedback, please email our Impact and Sustainability Department at impact@royalmt.com.np

Thank you to Outside, a digital agency studio based in Kathmandu, for helping us with the strategy and design of our first impact report.
